intro: Camphorosma lessingii var. pulviniformis, commonly known as the narrowleaf camphorosma, is a perennial shrub native to the western United States. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its aromatic, glandular leaves. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is adapted to arid or semi-arid environments. Its small, yellowish-green flowers appear in umbels, and the leaves are usually narrow and linear. This variety is distinguished by its unique leaf shape and is often found in chaparral and sagebrush habitats.
